Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and
your contract.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.

ALLEGATION:
Staff conducted an unwarranted restraint on youth.
2

INVESTIGATION:
A phone call was received from the Chief Administer (CA) on 2/15/22. He indicated a
staff member conducted a restraint when one was not needed.
Interviews:
Chief Administrator (CA) was interviewed face to face at the facility on 2/23/22. CA
reported Staff 1 was written up for the restraint he performed on 2/14/22. Staff 1 is a
supervisor and the Non-violent Crisis Intervention (restraint technique) trainer. His
supervisor is the Manager. CA reported him or the Manager will be present when
Staff 1 conducts his trainings, and they will utilize this incident in their training. The
CA was asked about spiritual hour and he reported it was an optional time for the
youth to be in their rooms.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on 2/17/22 and 2/23/22. He
reported he was restrained on Monday (2/14/22). He would not say who restrained
him. He was restrained face up after first being on his belly. He was mad so they
restrained him. He was not unsafe and did not need to be restrained. He was not
injured and did not have any concerns. He stated he likes Staff 1 because Staff 1 is
funny. When Staff 1 restrained him Staff 1 was mad and tried to push Youth A to the
wall, but he pushed Youth A to the couch then to the ground. Staff 1 did not have
any weight on his shoulder, but the other staff had their hands on his shoulders.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 2/23/22. He reported Youth A
was anxious after dinner and was acting erratically. Staff 1 was the supervisor who
was on shift, so he was called to the house. Youth A started to ride around on the
desk chairs. When Youth A got off the chair Staff 1 tried to take the chair and scoot it
away. Staff 4 tried to move the other chair away and Youth A grabbed the chair.
Staff 1 then went to engage Youth A because he was concerned about how Youth A
would respond to Staff 4. Staff 1 was facing Youth A, so he grabbed Youth A's
forearms. Youth A then went backwards and Staff 1 went forward. They tumbled
over the arm of the couch and landed on the floor. He was not sure how Youth A's
body landed. They ended face to face on the floor. He tried utilizing the interim
control position. Staff 1 stated he was on Youth A's side. Youth A has issues with
female staff, so he had it in his head that he needed to physically intervene to keep
Staff 4 (female staff) safe. Staff 1 grabbed onto Youth A's arms, and they fell over
the couch. Youth A then started to fight. He continued the hold due to safety. When
the two of them landed on the ground he was over the top of Youth A's body. He did
not put any weight on Youth A's body but remained on his tip toes, so he was not
restricting Youth A's breathing. Other staff came to assist. Staff 4 was holding Youth
A's lower half and her foot was hurting her, so she switched out with Staff 5. Staff 1
held Youth A's right arm and Staff 5 was holding his left. Staff 2 and Staff 3 came to
assist. Staff 1 disengaged, and Staff 3 took his place with Staff 2 on Youth A’s legs.
He removed himself as he was the focus of Youth A's anger. Staff 1 stated they are
taught to disengage a hold when it is safe to do so. He stated when Youth A was
biting and spitting it was more serious than the previous unsafe situation that caused
him to initiate the hold.
3

The Manager was interviewed face to face at the facility on 3/23/22. The manager
stated he is Staff 1's direct supervisor. He has not had any concerns with Staff 1.
Staff 1 is very knowledgeable about Non-violent Crisis Intervention (NVCI) and just
became certified to train. The Manager reviewed the video of the incident with Staff
1 and Youth A. He stated people perceive a crisis or a threat differently. He believes
there is always something that can be done different in a restraint. He stated things
are spiraling out of control because staff cannot restrain the youth.
Staff 3 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 2/23/22. Staff 3 was called to
the house. Youth A was banging his head on the ground and was already in team
control. Youth A was on the floor next to the couch. Staff 2 and Staff 5 were holding
Youth A on the ground. Staff 1 distanced himself from the situation because Youth A
was threatening Staff 1. He stated they are taught to back away from a youth when
they are trying to hurt them and that they can only restrain if there is intent to harm.
Staff 4 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 2/23/22. She reported Youth A
was upset due to his phase being frozen. They have spiritual hour in their room, so
he was supposed to be in his room. He refused to be in his room and started to say
he was going to hurt himself. He finally went into his room and would not let the staff
in. He was kicking the door when she was standing between the door and the frame.
Youth A heard Staff 1's voice and he opened the door. Youth A left his room and
began to mess with the chairs. Staff 4 grabbed a chair to keep it from him but Youth
A grabbed it, so she let go. Staff 1 then went into a restraint with Staff 5 helping.
They went into the quiet area. She did not see how they got to the ground. She had
a cramp, so another staff took over for her. Youth A was banging his head on the
ground and spitting. She stated it happened too quick to really see how Youth A was
being held when they went to the ground. Once on the ground Staff 1 was holding
onto one of Youth A's arms. She never saw any part of Staff 1 on Youth A. She did
not have any concerns about the restraint. She stated they can restrain when there
is risky behavior, or it is unsafe. Staff 1 thought Youth A was being aggressive.
When Youth A is in that mindset, he is bound to do whatever.
Staff 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 2/23/22. She stated she is a
supervisor on the weekends and the medical coordinator. She was called to Youth
A's house via emergency procedures. She called the police per Staff 1's request.
Staff 4 was hurt, and this left Staff 5 trying to gain control of Youth A. Staff 1 was
straddling over the top of Youth A but he did not have any weight on Youth A. Staff 1
was holding Youth A with one hand and holding Youth A's shirt up with the other
hand. Staff 1 had one leg up with his foot on the floor and the other knee was down
on the floor. Staff 3 came and took over for Staff 1. Staff 1 then helped hold Youth
A's legs. Youth A was spitting, biting, and banging his head on the ground. She
stated the other two staff were newer staff so the restraint could have been
smoother. Staff 2 stated that spiritual hour is supposed to be in their room and quiet
for an hour. There are consequences if the youth do not comply.
4

Video Reviewed:
Video was provided by the CA and viewed at the facility on 2/23/22. It was viewed
again with the Area Manager via Zoom. The video showed Youth A walking around
the great room. He began to play with the chairs. Staff 2 pulls a chair away from
Youth A, Youth A lets go and backs toward the wall. Staff 1 grabs Youth A from the
front. They end up falling over the arm of the couch and landing on the floor. Staff 1
is facing Youth A and straddling over the top of him. He uses one arm to hold Youth
A's shoulder and the other hand to pull up Youth A's shirt or coat to cover Youth A’s
face with it. Staff 1's knee holds down Youth A's other shoulder and arm. Youth A
tries to lift up his shoulders, but Staff 1 uses his knee to press Youth A to the floor.
Other staff come in and take over for Staff 1.
During the video review the CA admitted this was not a restraint technique that they
teach.
Documents Reviewed:
 Incident Report dated 2/14/22: With the exception of the following the rest of the
incident report was consistent with the staff’s interviews. Staff 1 thought Youth A
was going to pick up the chair and throw it. This then led to Staff 1 engaging
Youth A in a hold. Youth A resisted and the two of them fell over the couch
landing on the floor. The report did not indicate Staff 1 conducted an unapproved
restraint technique or that he was straddling over the top of Youth A.
 Staff 1 Employee File: Staff 1 had five disciplines in his file including the one
from this incident. The other disciplines were for attendance and supervision.
 Youth A’s Release Plan: Youth A has a history of aggressive and destructive
behavior, self-harm and manipulation. He made improvements while in the
program and returned to his parent’s home on 3/9/22.
 Behavior Management Philosophy and Procedures: Physical intervention can
only occur when there is a clear risk of impenitent harm. Emergency floor
procedures are no longer permitted, if a physical intervention ends up on the floor
staff must disengage the youth, help bring the youth to his knees or a standing
position, or utilize an escort position, in situations in which the previous 3 options
are not viable youth can be moved to a supine position. Crisis Prevention
Institute: NVCI Training Materials: Interim control is a position in which two staff
stand at each of the youth’s sides holding onto their arm with one hand and their
shoulder with the other then the youth is bent forward, team control can also be
done in a kneeling position, and interim control is used with one staff member
who stands to the side of the youth holding one of the youth’s arms in front of the
staff and the other to the side. It also states, “…when a forcefully maintained
position hinders both chest and abdomen movement, the result can be fatal.”
5

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.159 Resident restraint.
(2) Resident restraint shall be performed in a manner that is
safe, appropriate, and proportionate to the severity of the
minor child’s behavior, chronological and developmental
age, size, gender, physical condition, medical condition,
psychiatric condition, and personal history, including any
history of trauma, and done in a manner consistent with the
resident’s treatment plan
(4) The written policy shall only permit the licensee to
restrain a child for the following circumstances:
(a) To prevent injury to the child, self-injury, or injury to
others.
ANALYSIS: Staff 1 restrained Youth A even though he was not trying to
injure anyone. Staff 1 admitted he misread the situation. The
video showed Youth A was not posing a risk to anyone when he
was restrained. The restraint Staff 1 utilized on Youth A was not
performed in a safe manner. The video showed Staff 1
straddling Youth A with one knee on Youth A’s shoulder and
holding Youth A’s jacket over his face.
CONCLUSION: REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
